results.title: Dragon's Lair
results.brief_description: Dragon’s Lair looks more like a cartoon than a videogame. That’s because it was animated by Don Bluth, the legend behind The Land Before Time (1988), and its LaserDisc technology allowed for dramatically better graphics and sound than other games of the era.

constellations_primary.name: Dragon's Lair
constellations_primary.description: A look at pop-cultural interconnections that spawn from the lair of Don Bluth's arcade classic.

results.description:
Dragon’s Lair looks more like a cartoon than a videogame. There are two reasons for that: it was animated by legend Don Bluth, the man behind The Land Before Time (1988); and it used LaserDisc technology, allowing for dramatically better graphics and sound than other games released in 1983.

It was advertised as the first truly 3D videogame, but it maybe should’ve been advertised as the hardest videogame. Notorious for its difficulty, the gameplay features timed button/stick movements to advance the story and was deliberately designed to eat up as many coins as possible, even though it was already twice as expensive as typical games.

Despite the game being a little frustrating to casual players, Dragon’s Lair’s beautiful animation and unique gameplay means it has endured in pop-culture consciousness: it’s featured in many films and TV shows, including Family Guy (1999) and Stranger Things (2016).
description_for_label:

It was advertised as the first truly 3D videogame, but it maybe should’ve been advertised as the hardest videogame. Notorious for its difficulty, the gameplay features timed button/stick movements to advance the story and was deliberately designed to eat up as many coins as possible, even though it was already twice as expensive as typical games.

Despite the game being a little frustrating to casual players, Dragon’s Lair’s beautiful animation and unique gameplay means it has endured in pop-culture consciousness: it’s featured in many films and TV shows, including Family Guy (1999) and Stranger Things (2016).

results.title: down among the wild men / colonial imagination
results.material_description: Video loop, artist and Michael Bonner (performer)
results.brief_description: Shadow play, projection and performance combine to question our history and shift the colonial gaze in Ali Gumillya Baker’s mixed media video installation.

constellations_primary.name: The drama and nuance of silhouette
constellations_primary.description: Ali Gumillya Baker uses silhouette to evocative effect in her work reimagining the colonial gaze. The lighting technique has long been employed by filmmakers for its ability to dramatically convey a wide variety of emotions in everything from film noir to animation and whimsy.

constellations_other.name: Keep the fire burning
constellations_other.description: Yanmeeyarr, meaning ‘flickering in firelight’, shares how light and shadow are at the core of the moving image. It reflects the past, present and future of stories told by First Peoples utilising these elements, as well as bringing to light stories that have, for too long, been kept in the dark.

results.title_for_label: down among the wild men / colonial imagination
results.description:
Shadow play, projection and performance combine to question our history and shift the colonial gaze in Ali Gumillya Baker’s mixed media video installation.

“This is a violent black tragedy, a cathartic melodrama. Dressed in a tall ship hat pretending to be a colonialist, the Mirning artist writes with her feather quill back to the colonial-mother-monarch of her times ‘down among the wild men’. From the shade of the gum tree. At the same time as her chronicling, she is attacked by a wild man, (fellow sovereign Yanyuwa artist), who with a super large fork pretend stabs her in the back and the pretend explorer/tall ship coloniser collapses. Even the trees are scared of us blackfellas the hand holding the tree is shaking in fear. The background soundtrack that the viewer cannot hear is us all laughing maniacally at the re-enactment of the anthropological and colonial gaze.” - Ali Gumillya Baker
description_for_label:
Shadow play, projection and performance combine to question our history and shift the colonial gaze in Ali Gumillya Baker’s mixed media video installation.

“This is a violent black tragedy, a cathartic melodrama. Dressed in a tall ship hat pretending to be a colonialist, the Mirning artist writes with her feather quill back to the colonial-mother-monarch of her times ‘down among the wild men’. From the shade of the gum tree. At the same time as her chronicling, she is attacked by a wild man, (fellow sovereign Yanyuwa artist), who with a super large fork pretend stabs her in the back and the pretend explorer/tall ship coloniser collapses. Even the trees are scared of us blackfellas the hand holding the tree is shaking in fear. The background soundtrack that the viewer cannot hear is us all laughing maniacally at the re-enactment of the anthropological and colonial gaze.” - Ali Gumillya Baker

results.title: Documenting reality
results.brief_description: Documentary has evolved from educational newsreels and public service announcements to the experimental cinéma vérité (‘truthful cinema’), docuseries and online videos. They have also been used to spread propaganda and influence society, projecting interpretations of the truth that highlight the problematic relationship between cinema and reality.

constellations_primary.name: Reality TV me
constellations_primary.description: Cult documentary Grey Gardens follows the everyday eccentricities of mother and daughter Big Edie and Little Edie. The women perform and speak candidly to the camera, and have been described as predecessors to reality TV stars.

results.description: The very first films could be considered documentaries. Founders of the moving image, like Thomas Edison and the Lumière brothers, captured shorts of real life, called ‘actuality films’, at the turn of the 20th century. In the decades since, documentary has evolved from educational newsreels and public service announcements to the experimental cinéma vérité (‘truthful cinema’), docuseries and online videos. Documentary films have provided insight into others, revealed distant locations and forged deep connections between audiences and stories. But they have also been used to spread propaganda and influence society, projecting interpretations of the truth that highlight the problematic relationship between cinema and reality.
description_for_label: The very first films could be considered documentaries. Founders of the moving image, like Thomas Edison and the Lumière brothers, captured shorts of real life, called ‘actuality films’, at the turn of the 20th century. In the decades since, documentary has evolved from educational newsreels and public service announcements to the experimental cinéma vérité (‘truthful cinema’), docuseries and online videos. Documentary films have provided insight into others, revealed distant locations and forged deep connections between audiences and stories. But they have also been used to spread propaganda and influence society, projecting interpretations of the truth that highlight the problematic relationship between cinema and reality.

results.title: Documenting Australia
results.brief_description: Documenting Australia is a section in Moving Minds that explores how the identity of a nation can be crafted through the moving image.

constellations_primary.name: Women in charge
constellations_primary.description: Across documentary, film, TV, and visual art, Aboriginal women have led how they will be represented on-screen.

results.description:
The identity of a nation can be crafted through the moving image. While Australian narrative features say a lot about us as a people, few forms can cut through to the essence of Australia more acutely than documentary.  

In the post-war period, it emerged as one of the most important art forms in the local industry for its educational, political and social power. During the 1970s, documentary became an integral way for First Peoples to represent their experience on an unprecedented scale.

Decades later, documentary has endured and evolved as a way to amplify countless voices and ideas.
description_for_label:
The identity of a nation can be crafted through the moving image. While Australian narrative features say a lot about us as a people, few forms can cut through to the essence of Australia more acutely than documentary.  

In the post-war period, it emerged as one of the most important art forms in the local industry for its educational, political and social power. During the 1970s, documentary became an integral way for First Peoples to represent their experience on an unprecedented scale.

Decades later, documentary has endured and evolved as a way to amplify countless voices and ideas.

results.title: Dissolving effects slides
results.brief_description: Day becomes night over Loch Eck in these dissolving magic lantern slides. Dissolves created transitions between scenes by superimposing matching projections and carefully dimming one slide while brightening the other.
results.description:
Dissolves created transitions between scenes by superimposing matching projections and carefully dimming one slide while brightening the other. 

Other common dissolving effects included transforming black-and-white images into dazzling colour and conjuring heavenly or devilish figures into scenes to bewitch and beguile audiences. Like many techniques born from the visual language of magic lanterns, the dissolve effect was incorporated into filmmaking and is still used today.
description_for_label:
